message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome, which is common in pregnant women due to the increased fluid retention and swelling. Pre-pregnancy obesity can also increase the risk of developing this condition. Corticosteroid injections are generally avoided in pregnant women, but it is not specific to carpal tunnel syndrome. Immobilization, such as splinting, can improve symptoms in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). CTS is common in pregnant women due to fluid retention and increased susceptibility to nerve compression. Obesity is a risk factor for developing CTS, but it is not specific to pregnancy. Corticosteroid injections are generally safe in pregnancy, but should be used with caution. Immobilization of the affected hand with splinting can help alleviate symptoms in CTS.
